text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full–page illustration organized as a three–by–three grid of equally sized compartments, each framed by painted borders of green and blue with gold infill; no main body text on the page, wide blank margins surrounding the central composition

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf used as unifying background in every compartment to convey sacred space; blue and red drapery denote high status of figures (Christ, Moses, apostles); green framing establishes architectural rhythm; white highlights articulate folds and flesh modeling; color alternation in panels guides the eye through the typological sequence

features: Central Resurrection panel emphasized by scalloped arch
Peripheral panels present Old Testament prefigurations and NT episodes
Uniform halo placement creating visual rhythm
Horizontal and vertical axis aligning key figures

decorative_elements: Micro-architectural frames with alternating green and blue surrounds
Scalloped arch motif in central compartment

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill‐pen outlines in brown ink with varied weight, bold contours defining figure silhouettes and fine internal detail
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal tonal modeling using parallel white highlights and subtle hatching in robes and flesh
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling of figures by spiritual importance, overlapping only to indicate basic depth, no true linear perspective

scene_relationships.subject: Annunciation to the Virgin Mary
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Prefigures Christ’s incarnation before his Ascension
visual_connections: Gold background continues
Red drapery echoes in next panel
White scroll underpins divine message

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to portrayal of Moses receiving divine law as covenantal foreshadowing

Gold punctuations at frame corners

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Typologically linked to the warrior delivering Israel in next panel

Stone tablet shape repeated in panel frames

scene_relationships.subject: Israelite warrior defeating enemy
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Prefigures Christ’s victory over death in central Resurrection scene
visual_connections: Arm posture mirrored by angel’s raised hand
Use of chain‐mail patterning repeated
Diagonal composition element continues towards center

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Completes New Testament cycle before Old Testament deliverers below

Scroll design matches angel’s scroll
Gesture direction moves viewer downward

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Prefigures David’s victory over Goliath to the right
visual_connections: Lion’s posture leads eye to central pelican panel

scene_relationships.subject: Pelican feeding her young (Eucharistic symbol)
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Symbolically links Old Testament deliverance to Christ’s sacrifice in adjacent David scene

Gold highlights on beak match halos

scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Concludes typological sequence of deliverance prefiguring Christ’s triumph

Circular shield shape mirrors pelican nest

visual_continuity: Uniform halo treatment with punched decorations
Alternating blue and green framing borders
Hierarchical figure scaling highlighting central Resurrection

content_theme.scene_description: The central panel depicts the angel of the Resurrection seated on the marble sarcophagus, clad in a white tunic with burnished gold halo. He raises his right hand toward the three myrrhbearers to the right, who stand veiled in muted ochre and white draperies. Their garments feature fine lead‐white highlights and delicate plummet underdrawing visible under UV. The sarcophagus lid lies cast aside, painted in deep red with white stitch-pattern ornament. The ground is covered in stylized green pebbles, articulated by fine brushwork. A scalloped arch of blue and green frames the scene, its underside decorated with diapered gold. The angel’s scroll reads “Non timete vos quaeritis Iesum”, linking directly to New Testament text. Spatially, the figures occupy a shallow pictorial plane defined by overlapping—angel in front of tomb, women standing behind—and hierarchical scaling emphasizes the angel over the smaller myrrhbearers. Costumes display high status: the angel’s tunic has a faint weave pattern, while the women’s veils feature linear folds. Their posture, with heads inclined and hands clasped, directs attention back to the angel. Secondary elements include the scalloped arch itself as an architectural frame, punched halo ornamentation, and diapered background establishing sacred space. Symbolically, the angel embodies the divine messenger, the empty tomb signifies Christ’s victory, and the myrrhbearers represent the faithful witness. Text‐image integration is achieved through the scroll’s direct quotation of the Gospel narrative, and the empty margins reinforce the focus on the typological cycle presented.

architectural: Green and blue pilasters between compartments

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, extremely smooth parchment with visible hair-follicle pattern; full‐page quaternion gathering, consistent margins of approximately 5 cm
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent preservation; gold leaf fully burnished, ultramarine and vermilion remain vivid, minimal abrasion at edges, slight flaking of white highlights in few foliate details
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in halos and frames
Confident plummet underdrawing visible under UV illumination
Regular ruling pattern evident in compartment alignment
Brush-applied white highlighting stippled for flesh modeling
Punched diaper pattern in gold backgrounds

secondary_functions: Display of patron’s wealth through lavish illumination
Visual catechesis linking Old and New Testament
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Lay noble patron for personal devotional use

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This full–page typological cycle was likely produced in a high‐end court workshop in northern France during the first half of the 13th century, reflecting the era’s emphasis on linking Old Testament prefigurations with Christ’s redemptive work. The use of burnished gold leaf across all nine compartments situates each scene in a timeless, sacred realm, while the alternation of ultramarine and vermilion draperies signals both divine and royal associations. The grid layout recalls contemporary stained‐glass schemes, suggesting cross‐media influence and collaborative workshop practices. Technically, the confident underdrawing and layered application of white highlights demonstrate a mature Gothic artistry, likely the work of multiple hands under a master illuminator. Iconographically, the inclusion of the pelican feeding her young at the heart of the lower row offers a Eucharistic symbol that unites the typology of deliverance (Samson, David) with Christ’s self-sacrifice. The central Resurrection scene, with its scalloped arch and vivid green ground, anchors the viewer’s gaze and underscores the triumph over death. Comparatively, this manuscript shares stylistic affinities with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile—especially in its punched gold ornament and architectural framing—while advancing novelty through its tight grid and integrated textual scrolls. Overall, the page illustrates a sophisticated program of devotional imagery intended to instruct and inspire a noble lay audience within the broader context of 13th-century personal piety.
